creditline: Gift of Elizabeth, Julie, and Catherine Andrus in memory of John and Marion Andrus
description: six men in peasant clothing fighting with clubs, swords, daggers, and spears; woven fence with grapevines in background
inscription:
Signature, Date, Inscription, Label

-- inscribed in plate in banner: [HAVST DV MICH. SO STICH ICH DICH]
-- numbered in plate at upper left edge: 9
-- in graphite on verso: 7862 [with superscript \"2\"] | P185 I/II
-- in graphite on mount: P7439 / 1 of 6 
-- in graphite on back of mount: XP7439
-- label on mount: Christopher Mendez, 58 Jermyn Street London SW1Y 6LP / Telephone 01-491 0015
portfolio: From From Peasant Festival and Twelve Months, Plate 9
provenance: [Christopher Mendez, London; sold to Andrus]; John E. Andrus III, Wayzata, Minn.; by descent to his daughters, Elizabeth, Katie, and Julie; gave to MIA, 2015. Earlier provenances have been gathered, but further research will increase our knowledge of their histories.
signed: monogram in plate, upper center: [HSB] ; date in plate at top under banner: [1547]
text: Fights were popular features of peasant festivals, at least in art. The trigger might be flirting or cheating at games—and too much drink, as signaled by the grapevine at left. The banner reads, “If you clobber me, I’ll stick you.” The city of Nuremberg, which had become Lutheran shortly before this engraving was made, tried to suppress such celebrations. But they also came to represent the German birthright to have a good time.
title: Peasants' Brawl, From Peasant Festival or The Twelve Months, Plate 9
